com.googlecode.batchfb
Interface Batcher

All Known Implementing Classes:
Batch, FacebookBatcher
public interface Batcher

Interface to the Facebook APIs which allows you to define multiple requests (graph and fql) in advance and execute them in an optimal set of actual http calls to Facebook. Normal result values are mapped using Jackson; error results are unified into a standard exception hierarchy.

Two types of batching are currently supported:

  • Graph requests are batched using the Graph Batch mechanism.
  • FQL calls are batched into a single multiquery and then merged with the graph batch (if any).

Batches are limited to groups of 20. Any requests that exceed this number are executed in multiple requests. If your environment supports it (eg appengine), these requests will be executed concurrently.

See the User Guide for more information about how to use this class.

Author:
Jeff Schnitzer

Method Detail

graph

<T> GraphRequest<T> graph(java.lang.String object,
                          java.lang.Class<T> type,
                          Param... params)
Enqueue a Graph API call. The result will be mapped into the specified class.

Parameters:
object - is the object to request, eg "me" or "1234". Doesn't need to start with "/".
type - is the type to map the result to
params - are optional parameters to pass to the method.

graph

<T> GraphRequest<T> graph(java.lang.String object,
                          org.codehaus.jackson.type.TypeReference<T> type,
                          Param... params)
Enqueue a Graph API call. The result will be mapped into the specified type, which can be a generic class.

Parameters:
object - is the object to request, eg "me" or "1234". Doesn't need to start with "/".
type - is the Jackson type reference to map the result to (see the BatchFB UserGuide).
params - are optional parameters to pass to the method.

graph

GraphRequest<org.codehaus.jackson.JsonNode> graph(java.lang.String object,
                                                  Param... params)
Enqueue a Graph API call. The result will be left as a raw Jackson node type and will not be interpreted as a Java class.

Parameters:
object - is the object to request, ie "me" or "1234". Doesn't need to start with "/".
params - are optional parameters to pass to the method.

paged

<T> PagedLater<T> paged(java.lang.String object,
                        java.lang.Class<T> type,
                        Param... params)

Enqueue a Graph API call to an endpoint that results in paginated data. Any of the Facebook "connections" fit this pattern; the results look like:

{ data:[{...},{...}], paging:{previous:"http://blahblah", next:"http://blahblah"} } The PagedLater returned from this method can be used to navigate forwards and backwards in the pagination. For example, you could have a PagedLater that provides the list of User objects plus additional PagedLater for the next and previous pages.

Parameters:
object - is the connection object to request, eg "me/friends" or "1234/feed". Doesn't need to start with "/".
type - is the type of the element that will be paged across
params - are optional parameters to pass to the method.

query

<T> QueryRequest<java.util.List<T>> query(java.lang.String fql,
                                          java.lang.Class<T> type)
Enqueue a FQL call. The result will be interpreted as a list of the specified java class.

Parameters:
fql - is the query to run, which can include previously named query results
type - is what the contents of the resulting list will be mapped to

query

QueryRequest<org.codehaus.jackson.node.ArrayNode> query(java.lang.String fql)
Enqueue a FQL call. The result will be left as a raw Jackson array node.

Parameters:
fql - is the query to run, which can include previously named query results

queryFirst

<T> Later<T> queryFirst(java.lang.String fql,
                        java.lang.Class<T> type)
Just like query(), but retrieves the first value from the result set. If the result set is empty, the Later.get() value will be null.

Returns:
a later upon which you cannot set a name

queryFirst

Later<org.codehaus.jackson.JsonNode> queryFirst(java.lang.String fql)
Just like query(), but retrieves the first value from the result set. If the result set is empty, the Later.get() value will be null.

Returns:
a later upon which you cannot set a name

delete

Later<java.lang.Boolean> delete(java.lang.String object)
Enqueue a delete call to the Graph API.

post

Later<java.lang.String> post(java.lang.String object,
                             Param... params)
Enqueue a post (publish) call to the Graph API. Assumes the result has the standard format for graph posts (a simple string id wrapped in json).

Parameters:
params - can include a BinaryParam to post binary objects.

post

<T> Later<T> post(java.lang.String object,
                  java.lang.Class<T> type,
                  Param... params)
Enqueue a post (publish) call to the Graph API.

Parameters:
type - defines the expected return type from the call.
params - can include a BinaryParam to post binary objects.

execute

void execute()
Immediately start execution of the batch, asynchronously if possible. Normally there is no need to call this method explicitly; execution is triggered automatically when the first Later.get() call is made. If no calls are queued, nothing happens. If batch was already executed, nothing happens.
